Withdrawal Dates

   
February 21 Final day to withdraw from a course(s) for a 50% refund of tuition with a “W” grade(s) at the Registrar’s Office, H-214.
April 1 Final Day to withdraw from a course(s) for a “W” grade(s) at the Registrar’s Office, H-214.

Weekly schedule

Note that the syllabus schedule of work takes precedence.

  • Week 1. Personal Identity

    07/10-07/16

What we are doing each week

Find below links to notes, assignments, readings not in the textbook, and optional videos & readings. Consult the syllabus for a full list.

NB: Each ‘week’ outlines what you will be working on for a given week (see syllabus for the full details). The date after ‘week’ is our first meeting of the week. Readings for a particular week must be completed by that first meeting. There is also an assignment that you will work on during the week. The date indicates when it is due. Quizzes are both forward and backward looking. For instance, the quiz mentioned under ‘week 5’ will examine some of the material discussed during week 5 as well as some of the reading for week 6. Please ask if you have any questions.

Week 2 (1/23/17): Personal Identity

  • Reading
    • ‘A Dialog on Personal Identity and Immortality’, The First Night, J. Perry
    • `The Philosophy of Mind’, chapter 2. I include chapter 1 as well. You will need to purchase this textbook for future readings.
    • Meditations, Section 2 and 3, Descartes, optional
  • Handouts
    • Slides
  • Videos
    • Are we minds or bodies?
  • Assignments
    • Complete quiz 1 in Blackboard by 1/30/17

Week 3 (1/30/17): Dualism

  • Reading
    • Reading continued from week 2.
  • Assignments
    • Complete quiz 2 in Blackboard by 2/6/17

Week 4 (2/6/17): Psychological Continuity

  • Reading
    • ‘A Dialog on Personal Identity and Immortality’, The Second Night, J. Perry
  • Assignments
    • Submit essay 1 through Blackboard by 2/13/17 at 9am.
      • Use this check sheet before submitting your paper.
      • Please use ‘attach file’ to upload the file. Do not use ‘write submission’ or send it as a message. See this screenshot

Week 5 (2/13/17): Behaviorism + Reading + Textbook, ch.3 + Assignments + No assignment for 2/20/17

Week 6 (2/20/17): Continued

  • No class on Monday.
  • Reading
    • Textbook, ch.3
  • Assignments
    • Complete quiz 3 in Blackboard by 2/27/17. Quiz 3 examines the reading for both weeks 6 & 7.
    • Extra Credit: Write a brief report on both talks. For each talk, write one paragraph summarizing the main points and one short paragraph about your view of the material.
      • 3 points. Credit is awarded for completing both talks.
      • Submit the report through Blackboard under assignments.

Week 7 (2/27/17): Mind-Brain Identity Theory

  • Reading
    • Textbook, ch.4
    • ‘They’re Made Out of Meat’, Terry Bisson
  • Assignments
    • Complete essay 2 in Blackboard by 3/6/17
      • Essay check list

Spring Break (3/6/17) Relax and recharge

Week 8 (3/13/17): Functionalism & AI

You can find the slides for weeks 8 & 9 here.

  • Reading
    • Textbook, ch.5, pp. 129–138, 156–159
    • ‘Computing Machinery and Intelligence’, A.M.Turing
    • Philosophy and the creation of computers, optional fun read.
  • Videos
    • Necessary and Sufficient Conditions
    • The Imitation Game, optional movie about Turing. Available online on Amazon and elsewhere.
    • Star Trek: The Measure of a Man optional TV episode that touches on the issues for this week.
  • Assignments
    • Complete quiz 4 in Blackboard by 3/20/17

Week 9 (3/20/17): Problems with Functionalism

You can find the slides for weeks 8 & 9 here.

  • Reading
    • Textbook, ch.5, pp. 156–165
    • ‘Is the Brain’s Mind a Computer Program?’, J. Searle
    • ‘Troubles with Functionalism’, N. Block (optional)
  • Videos
    • A reconstruction of the Chinese Room Thought Experiment
    • AI: Computers and Minds
  • Assignments
    • Complete essay 3 and submit it through Blackboard by 3/27/17
      • Essay check list
      • Sample response: a student’s A-paper from a former university

Week 10 (3/27/17) Mental Causation

  • Reading
    • Textbook, ch.7, pp.193–209; 214–217
    • ‘Mental Causation’, Sections 1-4,7-8, S.Yablo
  • Assignments
    • Complete quiz 5 in Blackboard by 4/3/17

Week 11 (4/3/17): Continued

No class on Monday

Week 12 (4/10/17): Varieties of Consciousness

  • Reading
    • Textbook, ch.9, 263–280
    • ‘What is it like to be a bat?’, pp.435–442, T. Nagel
  • Assignments
    • Complete quiz 6 in Blackboard by 4/17/17
  • Videos
    • How do you explain consciousness?, David Chalmers

Week 13 (4/17/17): Self Consciousness: Introspection + Reading + Textbook, ch.9, pp.280–289 + ‘Knowing Our Minds’, A. Byrne + ‘Consciousness as Internal Monitoring’, William G. Lycan (optional) + Assignments + Complete essay 5 by 4/24/17 + Sample response from essay 4. This paper earned an A-. It would have received an A, if it had included more examples and a few more sentences about why the four claims are contradictory. + Notes: these are from the last two weeks.

Week 14 (4/24/17): Self Consciousness: Representationalism

  • Reading
    • Textbook, ch.9, pp.289ff
    • ‘How do you know you are not a Zombie’, F. Dretske
    • ‘The Mind’s Awareness of Itself’, F. Dretske (optional)
  • Assignments
    • Complete quiz 7 by 5/1/17
  • Other
    • Begin thinking about the signature assignment/final project.

    • Frank Jackson on What Mary Knew,
  • Other

  • Assignments
